title: If A (x^2 - x + 1) = x^4 + x^2 + 1, then A can be, (1) x^2 + x + 1 (2) x^2 - x + 1 (3) x^2 - x -1 (4) -x^2 + x - 1 ? PLEASE HELP - Quora

response.answer_text: First factorise (x^4 +x^2 +1) Factorising it, we have =(x^2+x+1) (x^2 - x +1) So, A (x^2-x +1)=(x^2+x+1) (x^2 - x +1) Or, A = x^2 +x +1…… option (1) is your answer….
